column1: #Text=World Bank says more people are poor , but fewer are in extreme poverty
#Text=According to a new study released by the World Bank , more people than thought are considered to be poor in the developing world but the percentage of people in extreme poverty have decreased .
#Text=The study finds that as of 2005 , there are 1.4 billion people who are living for less than US$ 1.25 per day .
#Text=This is down from 1.9 billion in 1981 , which equals half of the population in the developing world .
#Text=However , the new numbers have vastly increased from previous estimates .
#Text=According to last estimate based on data from 1994 , it was believed that there were only 985 million people in poverty in 2004 and 1.5 billion in 1981 .

#Text=The new data confirm that the world will likely reach the first Millennium Development Goal of halving the 1990 level of poverty by 2015 and that poverty has fallen by about one percentage point a year since 1981 .
#Text=Chief Economist and Senior Vice President , Development Economics at the World Bank

#Text=According to one of the report 's authors Martin Ravallion , Director of the Development Research Group at the World Bank , " The new estimates are a major advance in poverty measurement because they are based on far better price data for assuring that the poverty lines are comparable across countries .

#Text=Data from household surveys have also improved in terms of country coverage , data access , and timeliness .

_	_	_	_

#Text=The new data confirm that the world will likely reach the first Millennium Development Goal of halving the 1990 level of poverty by 2015 and that poverty has fallen by about one percentage point a year since 1981 ,  said Justin Lin , Chief Economist and Senior Vice President , Development Economics at the World Bank .

_	_	_	_

#Text=However , the sobering news that poverty is more pervasive than we thought means we must redouble our efforts , especially in Sub-Saharan Africa ,  added Lin .
